bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Act:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: clerk of the peace includes the proper officer of the court that has jurisdiction in an appeal under this Act;
common jail or prison means any place, other than a penitentiary, in which persons charged with offences are usually kept and detained in custody;
copy means, in relation to a violation ticket that is an eTicket, a printout, in the prescribed form, that is produced from the digital record of the eTicket;
district or county includes any territorial or judicial division or place in and for which there is a judge, justice, justice's court, officer or prison as is mentioned in the context;
eCertificate of service means a certificate of service described in section 31.01;
enforcement officer means any person or class of persons designated as an enforcement officer under section 132;
eTicket means a violation ticket described in section 14.01;
fine includes any supplemental fine amount, or other additional monetary penalty, established under an enactment;
informant means a person who lays an information or an enforcement officer who issues a violation ticket;
information includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a violation ticket,
a count in an information or in a violation ticket, and
a complaint in respect of which a justice is authorized to make an order;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: justice means a justice of the peace, and includes 2 or more justices, if 2 or more justices act or have jurisdiction, and a judge of the Provincial Court or any person who has the power or authority of 2 or more justices of the peace;
optional conditions means the conditions referred to in section 89.2 that may be included in a probation order;
order includes an order for the payment of money;
probation order means a probation order made under section 89;
proceedings means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceedings in respect of offences, and
proceedings in which a justice is authorized by an enactment to make an order;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: prosecutor means an informant or the Attorney General or their respective counsel or agents;
territorial division means a district, county, township, city, town or other judicial division or place;
ticketed amount means, in relation to an alleged contravention of an enactment, for which a violation ticket is issued under section 14, the aggregate of the following amounts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fine prescribed for the contravention or, if 2 fines are prescribed for the contravention, the fine payable at the time of payment;
the victim surcharge levy to be paid with that fine under section 8.1 of the Victims of Crime Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: trial includes the hearing of a complaint;
violation ticket means a violation ticket referred to in section 14 but does not include the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3).

bcl:section.bcl:text: An offence created under an enactment is punishable on summary conviction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except where otherwise provided by law, this Act applies to proceedings as defined in section 1.

If no time is specially limited for making a complaint or laying an information in the Act or law relating to the particular case, proceedings must not be instituted more than 6 months after the time when the subject matter of the proceedings arose.
An action or suit must not be brought for a penalty or forfeiture under an Act except within 6 months after the cause of action arises, unless the time is otherwise limited by the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless otherwise specifically provided in an enactment, a person who is convicted of an offence is liable to a fine of not more than $2 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or to both.
A person who contravenes an enactment by doing an act that it forbids, or omitting to do an act that it requires to be done, commits an offence against the enactment.
Despite section 4 or the provisions of any other Act, no person is liable to imprisonment with respect to an absolute liability offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every person who is taken into custody by a peace officer is entitled, on request to the person responsible for his or her custody, to have access to, and the private use of, a telephone as soon as possible at least once during the first 12 hours of his or her custody.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, hinders or prevents a person in custody from exercising the right granted by subsection (1), commits an offence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 2.1 of the Provincial Court Act, every justice has jurisdiction to try, determine and adjudge proceedings to which this Act applies in the territorial division over which the justice has jurisdiction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For this Act, if an offence is committed in or on any water or on a bridge between 2 or more territorial divisions, the offence is deemed to be committed in any of the territorial divisions.

For this Act, if an offence is committed on the boundary of 2 or more territorial divisions or within 450 m of a boundary, or the offence was commenced in one territorial division and completed in another, the offence is deemed to be committed in any of the territorial divisions.
Judicial notice must be taken of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a proclamation or order of the Lieutenant Governor in Council;
a regulation made by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under an Act;
a regulation made under an Act;
a regulation published in the Gazette.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Judicial notice must be taken of the publication of any of the matters referred to in subsection (1).
An order or conviction must not be quashed or set aside, and a defendant must not be discharged, merely because evidence has not been given of any of the matters referred to in subsection (1).
In this section, data record means a record in an electronic or other format but does not include a record in paper format.
This section does not apply to a violation ticket.

If a rule of law, custom or practice requires information to be recorded or presented in writing, the requirement is deemed to be satisfied if the information is recorded or presented in a format that enables the information to be subsequently displayed or immediately accessible in visible form.
If a rule of law, custom or practice requires information to be signed or endorsed, the requirement is deemed to be satisfied in the case of a data record if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a method of authentication is used to indicate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by whom the data record was created or communicated, and
that the person who is required to sign or endorse the record approved of the information in the record, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the method of authentication is reliable and appropriate for that data record.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a rule of law, custom or practice requires information to be presented in its original form, the requirement is deemed to be satisfied in the case of a data record by the presentation of the data record or a paper copy of the data record if there is a reasonable assurance as to the integrity of the information being presented.
A data record is deemed to maintain the integrity of the information being presented even though the information in the data record is modified if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any modifications to the information in the data record are documented in a manner that records the name of the person authorizing the modification, the name of the person making the modification, the date and time when the modification was made and the content of the modification, and
the information referred to in paragraph (a) is available for presentation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses a data record for the purpose of making a statement under oath must, instead of swearing or affirming an oath, sign a statement in accordance with subsection (3) that all matters contained in the data record are true to the person's knowledge and belief, and a data record containing such a statement is deemed to be made under oath.

This section must not be construed to limit the use of a data record or to prevent the signing, endorsement or presentation of a data record in any other manner authorized under an enactment or allowed by a court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Proceedings must be commenced by the laying of an information in Form 2 or by means of a violation ticket under section 14.
Despite any other law that requires an information to be laid before, or to be tried by, 2 or more justices, one justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receive the information,
issue a summons or warrant with respect to the information, and
do all other things preliminary to the trial.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An information

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be in writing, other than an information laid by means of an eTicket,
must be under oath, other than an information laid by means of a violation ticket, and

may charge more than one offence or relate to more than one matter of complaint, but if more than one offence is charged or the information relates to more than one matter of complaint, each offence or matter of complaint must be set out in a separate count.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An information in respect of an offence for which, because of previous convictions, a greater punishment may be imposed must not contain any reference to previous convictions.

If a matter is prescribed for the purpose of section 4 (2) of the Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act, no proceeding may be commenced by an information, including a violation ticket, under this Act in respect of the contravention of a local government or City of Vancouver bylaw made in relation to the matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information laid by means of telecommunication

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A peace officer may lay an information by any means of telecommunication that produces a writing.

A peace officer who uses a means of telecommunication for the purpose of laying an information must, instead of swearing an oath, make a statement in writing stating that all matters contained in the information are true to the peace officer's knowledge and belief, and such a statement is deemed to be a statement made under oath.
An enforcement officer may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sign and issue a violation ticket, other than an eTicket, for contravention of an enactment referred to in the regulations, or
issue an eTicket for contravention of an enactment referred to in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of a violation ticket issued to the owner of a motor vehicle in respect of an offence under section 83.1 (2) or (2.1) of the Motor Vehicle Act but without limiting the application of subsection (1) of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the violation ticket may be created, completed and signed in electronic format by electronic or any other means that allows the violation ticket to be reproduced in intelligible form including, without limitation, electronically,

in place of signing the violation ticket under subsection (1), the enforcement officer may identify himself or herself as the person making and authenticating the violation ticket by means of an electronic reproduction of his or her signature that is capable of being assigned to that violation ticket only by that enforcement officer,

the signature referred to in paragraph (b) may be made by electronic or any other means that allows the signature to be reproduced in intelligible form including, without limitation, by electronically storing the signature by means of an electronic scanner or an electronic signature pad,

if the violation ticket including the enforcement officer's signature is in electronic format, it may be converted from electronic format to paper format for all purposes including, without limitation, for the purposes of subsections (5) and (6),
if the violation ticket including the enforcement officer's signature is in electronic format, it may be received, transmitted, stored or sent electronically,
if the violation ticket is sent to the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia in paper format for storage, the corporation may convert it to and store it in electronic format, and
if the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia has stored the violation ticket in electronic format under paragraph (e) or (f),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the corporation may provide the violation ticket or a copy of it by reproducing it in electronic format or paper format, or on a record that enables the information to be subsequently displayed or immediately accessible in visible form, and
the reproduction referred to in subparagraph (i) has the same effect for all purposes as if it were an original document, if the reproduction

bcl:clause.bcl:text: is certified in writing by an officer of the corporation as being a true reproduction of all the information on the violation ticket, or
contains a statement that it is an authentic reproduction of all the information on a violation ticket stored in a database in electronic format by the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A violation ticket is valid even though it is not taken under oath.
A violation ticket that is mailed under subsection (6) or served must be in the prescribed form and must contain all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of the alleged contravention;
a statement of the ticketed amount applicable to the alleged contravention;
an address to which a notice disputing the allegation or the fine portion of the ticketed amount may be delivered;
a statement that if the allegation or fine is not disputed within the time provided in this Act

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the violation ticket will be treated as not disputed,
the person on whom the ticket is served will be deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention, and
the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket will be payable to the government;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a violation ticket issued in respect of an offence under section 83.1 (2) or (2.1) of the Motor Vehicle Act, a statement that if the allegation or fine is disputed within the time provided in section 15 (2) of this Act but the person to whom the ticket was mailed fails to appear before the Provincial Court to dispute the allegation or fine on a date referred to in section 15 (11) (a) or (b),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the violation ticket will be treated as not disputed,
the person will be deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention, and
the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket will be payable to the government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), the violation ticket must be sent to the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia and a copy of it must be served on the person alleged to have contravened the enactment.

A violation ticket that is sent to the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia under subsection (5) is not insufficient or invalid only because the instructions prescribed for the violation ticket under section 132 (2) (a.3) are not sent to the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia with the violation ticket.
A copy of a violation ticket issued in respect of an offence by an owner of a motor vehicle under section 83 (2.1) or 83.1 (2) or (2.1) of the Motor Vehicle Act may be sent

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by ordinary mail to the address of the owner as set out in the records of the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia, or
by registered mail to the address of the owner as set out in the records of the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If service is required by this section, an enforcement officer may serve, or cause to be served, a copy of the violation ticket on the person alleged to have contravened the enactment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately after the alleged contravention,
in the same manner as a summons is required to be served under this Act, or
outside the province in accordance with section 14.1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The use on a violation ticket of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any word or expression authorized by the regulations made under this Act or another Act to designate an offence, or
a general description of an offence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is deemed sufficient for all purposes to describe the offence designated by that word or expression.
Subject to subsection (10), the person on whom the violation ticket is served may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dispute an allegation or the amount of the fine portion of the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket in accordance with section 15, or
pay the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket in accordance with the prescribed instructions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a violation ticket issued in respect of an offence under section 83.1 (2) or (2.1) of the Motor Vehicle Act, the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on whom the ticket is served, or
to whom the ticket is mailed under subsection (6) of this section,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dispute an allegation or the amount of the fine portion of the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket in accordance with section 15 of this Act, or
pay the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket in accordance with the prescribed instructions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person pays all or a portion of the ticketed amount indicated on a violation ticket in accordance with subsection (9) or (10), the person is deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention and the unpaid portion of that ticketed amount is immediately payable to the government.
For the purposes of this Act, an eTicket is a type of violation ticket created as an electronic digital record but does not include a violation ticket referred to in section 14 (2).
An eTicket includes a printout or display, in the prescribed form, that is produced from the digital record of the ticket.
A printout or display of the digital record of an eTicket containing a statement that it is an authentic printout or display produced from the digital record is conclusive proof of that fact.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service of violation tickets outside British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A copy of a violation ticket may be served outside British Columbia in accordance with this section.
A copy of a violation ticket may be served outside British Columbia on an individual by an enforcement officer who must deliver it personally to the individual to whom it is issued.
A copy of a violation ticket may be served outside British Columbia on a corporation that does not have a registered or branch office in British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by an enforcement officer who must deliver it to a director, or to a manager, secretary or other executive officer, of the corporation or a branch of it, or

if after hearing evidence that a person referred to in paragraph (a) cannot be conveniently found, a justice so orders, by leaving it at, or by mailing it by registered post addressed to, the registered or principal office of the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Service under this section may be proven

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as authorized under section 31, or
by affidavit of the enforcement officer who effected service stating when, where and how service was effected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person on whom a violation ticket has been served may, within 30 days of being served, dispute the allegation or the fine portion of the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delivering or causing to be delivered to the address set out in the ticket or to an address set out in the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3) a written notice of dispute, or
appearing in person at the location set out in the ticket or at a location set out in the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3) to give notice of dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person to whom a violation ticket has been mailed under section 14 (6) (a) but on whom the ticket has not been served may, within 45 days from the date the ticket is completed, dispute the allegation or the fine portion of the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delivering or causing to be delivered to the address set out in the ticket or to an address set out in the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3) a written notice of dispute, or
appearing in person at the location set out in the ticket or at a location set out in the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3) to give notice of dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of dispute under this section must contain an address for the person disputing the allegation or fine and sufficient information to identify the violation ticket and the alleged contravention or the fine being disputed.
For the purpose of this section, a notice of dispute that is delivered by mail is deemed to have been delivered on the date on which it was mailed.
A copy of the violation ticket must be referred to the Provincial Court for a hearing when the notice of dispute containing the information referred to in subsection (3) is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delivered to the address set out in the violation ticket or the address set out in the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3), or
given at the location set out in the violation ticket or the instructions prescribed under section 132 (2) (a.3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a copy of the violation ticket is referred to the Provincial Court under subsection (5),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of hearing, or
a notice of appearance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be sent to the person disputing the allegation or fine at the address set out in the notice of dispute.
A copy of a violation ticket referred to the Provincial Court under subsection (5) may be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a microfilm or other photographic reproduction of the violation ticket that is certified in writing by an officer of the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia as being a true reproduction of the ticket, or

a reproduction of electronically stored information, whether in electronic or paper format or on any other record that enables the information to be subsequently displayed or immediately accessible in visible form, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is certified in writing by an officer of the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia as being a true reproduction of all the information on the violation ticket, or
contains a statement that it is an authentic reproduction of all the information on a violation ticket stored in a database in electronic format by the corporation,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and the reproduction is deemed to be a copy of the violation ticket.

Without restricting any other method of complying with subsection (5) in respect of eTickets, the requirement to refer a copy of an eTicket to the Provincial Court is satisfied if the digital record of the eTicket is referred to the court and the court can produce a printout or display, in the prescribed form, of the digital record.
When the Provincial Court receives a copy of a violation ticket, the court has jurisdiction to try, determine and adjudge proceedings relating to the violation ticket in accordance with section 8.

A copy of a violation ticket that is referred to the Provincial Court under subsection (5) and received by the Provincial Court under subsection (8) is not insufficient or invalid only because the instructions prescribed for the violation ticket under section 132 (2) (a.3) are not referred to and received by the Provincial Court with the violation ticket, and the court has jurisdiction to try, determine and adjudge proceedings relating to the violation ticket in accordance with section 8.

If a person appears before the Provincial Court at the hearing or appearance on the date set by a notice under subsection (6), section 58 does not apply with respect to the person and the court has jurisdiction to hear the dispute without

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: examining the notice of dispute, the notice of hearing or the notice of appearance,
inquiring into the service of the ticket on the person, or
inquiring into whether the person received instructions prescribed for the ticket under section 132 (2) (a.3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person fails to appear before the Provincial Court at the hearing or appearance on the date set by a notice under subsection (6), the person may, within 30 days after that date, appear before a justice for a determination of whether or not the failure to appear was the person's fault.
If a person appears before a justice under subsection (9.1) and the justice is satisfied by affidavit in the prescribed form that the failure to appear was not the person's fault, the justice must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cause a new date to be set for the hearing or appearance, and

order the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia or the superintendent to cancel or cease any administrative action that has been taken or commenced by the corporation or the superintendent, as the case may be, as a consequence of the person's failure to appear.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (12), if a person fails to appear before the Provincial Court at the hearing or appearance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the date set by a notice under subsection (6), or
on any other date set by a justice for a hearing or an appearance in relation to the violation ticket,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the allegation or fine is deemed not to be disputed, the Provincial Court must not try, determine or adjudge the proceedings and section 16 (1) applies.
If a person to whom a violation ticket is mailed under section 14 (6) (a) fails to appear before the Provincial Court on a date referred to in subsection (11) (a) or (b) of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the allegation or fine is deemed not to be disputed and the Provincial Court must not try, determine or adjudge the proceedings,
the person is deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention, and
the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket is immediately payable to the government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence admissible in trial on a violation ticket

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 60, a justice hearing the trial on a violation ticket may admit as evidence, whether or not it would be admissible under the laws of evidence, any oral or written testimony or any record or thing that the justice considers is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: relevant to an issue in the trial, and
credible and trustworthy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may not admit under subsection (1) anything that is privileged under the laws of evidence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedures in trial on a violation ticket

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 60, but subject to the applicable Rules of Court, a justice hearing the trial on a violation ticket may adopt procedures that are conducive to justly and expeditiously determining the matter.
On a trial of a violation ticket, the prosecutor may appear and prosecute

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by video conferencing, if video conferencing equipment is available at the location of the Provincial Court where the trial is held, or
by telephone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On a trial of a violation ticket for a prescribed offence, or for a prescribed offence in prescribed circumstances, the defendant may appear and defend

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by video conferencing, if video conferencing equipment is available at the location of the Provincial Court where the trial is held, or
by telephone.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate evidence of prescribed violation ticket offence admissible

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a hearing required under section 15 (5) is in respect of a prescribed offence, a certificate in the prescribed form, purporting to be signed by an enforcement officer and setting out evidence of the alleged offence, is admissible in the hearing without proof of the signature or official character of the enforcement officer appearing to have signed the certificate and is proof of the facts certified in it unless there is evidence to the contrary.
For the purpose of a certificate under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the certificate may be created, completed and signed in electronic format by electronic or any other means that allows the certificate to be reproduced in intelligible form including, without limitation, electronically,

in place of signing the certificate under subsection (1), the enforcement officer may identify himself or herself as the person making and authenticating the certificate by means of an electronic reproduction of his or her signature that is capable of being assigned to that certificate only by that enforcement officer,

the signature referred to in paragraph (b) may be made by electronic or any other means that allows the signature to be reproduced in intelligible form including, without limitation, by electronically storing the signature by means of an electronic scanner or an electronic signature pad,

if the certificate including the enforcement officer's signature is in electronic format, it may be converted from electronic format to paper format for all purposes including, without limitation, for the purpose of delivering the certificate to the court, and
if the certificate including the enforcement officer's signature is in electronic format, it may be received, transmitted, stored or sent electronically.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person against whom a certificate under this section is produced may, with leave of the court, require the attendance of the enforcement officer who signed the certificate, for the purpose of cross-examination, if in the opinion of the court cross-examination is necessary to determine a relevant issue before the court.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations for the purposes of this section, including regulations prescribing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the offences in respect of which a certificate under subsection (1) is admissible, and
the form of a certificate under subsection (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who delivers a notice of dispute under section 15 (1) or (2) in respect of only the fine portion of the ticketed amount indicated on a violation ticket may include with the notice, in the prescribed form,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement that he or she does not want to appear in person for a hearing of the dispute, and
written reasons for requesting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a reduction in the fine amount, or
time to pay under section 82 (2) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a notice of dispute includes the form referred to in subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the hearing required by section 15 (5) is satisfied by the consideration under paragraph (c),
section 15 (6) and (8) to (12) does not apply to the dispute,
the justice to whom the matter is referred must consider the reasons provided under subsection (1) (b) and make an order in the dispute in accordance with this Act, and
the order of the justice under paragraph (c) may be sent by ordinary mail to the person who delivered the notice under section 15 (1) or (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order of a justice sent under subsection (2) (d) is deemed to have been received on the 7th day after the date of mailing.

If a person who has been served with a violation ticket under section 14 has not, within 30 days after the ticket was served on the person, either paid all or a portion of the ticketed amount or disputed the allegation or the fine portion of the ticketed amount in accordance with section 15,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention, and
the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket is immediately payable to the government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), if a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is served with a violation ticket, and
is convicted under section 15 or deemed to have pleaded guilty under subsection (1)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: wishes to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine, the person must apply to a justice and the justice, on being satisfied of the matters in subsection (2.1) by affidavit in the prescribed form and with or without hearing from the applicant, may make an order striking out the conviction, if any, and allowing the person to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine portion of the ticketed amount in accordance with sections 15 to 15.4.
Before making an order under subsection (2) allowing a dispute to proceed, a justice must be satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: through no fault of the defendant, he or she did not have an opportunity to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine,
the defendant had a genuine intention to dispute the ticket before the dispute period under subsection (1) expired,
no undue prejudice will result from the extension of the dispute period,
the defendant has an arguable defence to the violation ticket, and
it is in the interests of justice to allow the dispute to proceed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to whom a violation ticket is mailed under section 14 (6) (a) but on whom the ticket has not been served, and
who was deemed to have pleaded guilty to the alleged contravention on the ticket under section 14 (11) or 15 (12)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: wishes to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine, the person must apply to a justice and the justice, on being satisfied of the matters in subsection (3.2) by affidavit in the prescribed form and with or without hearing from the applicant, may make an order striking out the conviction, if any, and allowing the person to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine portion of the ticketed amount in accordance with sections 15 to 15.4.
For the purposes of a hearing or appearance set in relation to a violation ticket under subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the affidavit referred to in subsection (3) constitutes a notice of dispute under section 15 and is deemed to have been given in accordance with section 15 (5) by the person to whom the ticket was mailed, and
section 15 (5) to (10) and (12) applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before making an order under subsection (3) allowing a dispute to proceed, a justice must be satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: through no fault of the defendant, he or she did not have an opportunity to dispute the allegation or the amount of the fine, and
less than 30 days elapsed between the date the conviction first came to the attention of the defendant and the date the defendant made the application under subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a conviction is struck out under subsection (2) or (3), the justice must, on request, give the person a certificate of the fact in the prescribed form.
Nothing in subsection (1) is to be construed as abrogating the right of a person to appeal the conviction under section 102.
A person to whom subsection (2) or (3) applies may not appeal to the appeal court from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a conviction to which those subsections apply, or
an order under those subsections.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person is deemed to have pleaded guilty to an alleged contravention under section 14 (11), 15 (12) or 16 (1) or is found guilty of an alleged contravention by the Provincial Court, no minute or memorandum of the conviction need be drawn up or entered unless it is required by the person or a prosecutor or under the enactment contravened.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Insurance Corporation of British Columbia must cancel a violation ticket that does not disclose an offence on its face.
A person designated under subsection (5) may cancel a violation ticket

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that, through no fault of the person named on the ticket, was served on a person other than the person so named, and
in respect of which the person named on the ticket was deemed to have pleaded guilty under section 14 (11), 15 (12) or 16 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person designated under subsection (5) may cancel a violation ticket that was mailed to a person under section 14 (6) if the person named on the ticket was deemed to have pleaded guilty under section 14 (11) but, through no fault of the person named on the ticket, all or a portion of the ticketed amount indicated on the ticket was paid by a person other than the person named.
A violation ticket that has been cancelled under this section is void and any conviction with respect to the ticket is deemed never to have occurred.
For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3), the Assistant Deputy Attorney General, Criminal Justice Branch, may designate in writing one or more persons.

The Insurance Corporation of British Columbia, in carrying out its responsibilities under this Act, must act in accordance with any directives issued by the Assistant Deputy Attorney General, Criminal Justice Branch.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the Assistant Deputy Attorney General, Criminal Justice Branch, may issue general or specific directives.

Nothing in this Act or any other law requires a justice before whom proceedings are commenced, or who issues process before or after the trial, to be the justice or one of the justices before whom the trial is held.

If 2 or more justices have jurisdiction with respect to proceedings, they must be present and act together at the trial, but after the trial one justice may do anything that is required or authorized to be done in connection with the proceedings.
Subject to section 20, only the justice before whom the trial is commenced has jurisdiction for the trial and adjudication, but any justice may adjourn the proceedings at any time

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before the plea of the defendant is taken, or
after the plea of the defendant is taken but before the trial is commenced.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourns a proceeding under subsection (3) (a) or (b), or
terminates a proceeding under section 31 (5) of the Provincial Court Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is not seized of the matter to which the proceeding relates.

If a trial is commenced before a justice and that justice dies or is for any reason unable to continue the trial, another justice for the same territorial division may act in the place of the justice before whom the trial was commenced.
A justice who, under subsection (1), acts in the place of a justice before whom a trial was commenced

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must, if an adjudication has been made by the justice in whose place he or she acts, impose the punishment or make the order that, in the circumstances, is authorized by law, or
must, if an adjudication has not been made by the justice in whose place he or she acts, commence the trial again as a new trial.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there is reasonable ground to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: anything on or in respect of which an offence has been or is suspected to have been committed, or
anything that there is reasonable ground to believe will afford evidence as to the commission of such an offence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: may issue and sign a warrant authorizing a person named in it or a peace officer to search the building, receptacle or place for that thing, and to seize the thing and to bring it or a report of it before the justice who issued the warrant or another justice for the same territorial division, to be dealt with under section 24.

If the building, receptacle or place in which anything mentioned in subsection (1) is believed to be is in another territorial division, the justice may issue a warrant in a similar form, modified according to the circumstances, and the warrant may be executed in the other territorial division after it has been endorsed in Form 16 by a justice who has jurisdiction in that territorial division.

An endorsement made on a warrant under subsection (2) is sufficient authority to the peace officers to whom it was originally directed, and to all peace officers within the jurisdiction of the justice by whom it is endorsed, to execute the warrant and to take the things to which it relates before the justice who issued the warrant or some other justice for the same territorial division.
A warrant issued under this section must be executed by day, unless the justice, by the warrant, authorizes execution of it by night.
A search warrant issued under this section may be in Form 3.

If a thing is seized under this section, as soon as reasonably possible after the seizure, the person who executed the warrant must bring the thing, or a report of the thing, before a justice to be dealt with under section 24.

If a peace officer believes that an offence punishable on conviction has been committed and that it would be impracticable to appear personally before a justice to apply for a warrant in accordance with section 21, the peace officer may submit an information on oath by telephone or other means of telecommunication to a justice designated for that purpose by the chief judge of the Provincial Court.

An information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication must be on oath and must be recorded word for word by the justice, who must, as soon as practicable, cause the record or a transcription of it, certified by the justice as to time, date and contents, to be filed with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution.
An oath under subsection (2) may be administered by telephone or other means of telecommunication.
An information on oath submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication must include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of the circumstances that make it impracticable for the peace officer to appear personally before a justice;
a statement of the offence alleged, the place or premises to be searched and the items alleged to be liable to seizure;
a statement of the peace officer's grounds for believing that the items liable to seizure in respect of the offence alleged will be found in the place or premises to be searched;
a statement as to any prior application for a warrant under this section or any other search warrant, in respect of the same matter, of which the peace officer has knowledge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who is satisfied that an information submitted under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: concerns an offence punishable on conviction under an enactment,
conforms to the requirements of subsection (4),
discloses reasonable grounds for dispensing with an information presented personally and in writing, and
discloses reasonable grounds, in accordance with section 21 (1) (a) or (b), for the issuance of a warrant in respect of an offence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: may issue a warrant to a peace officer that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confers the same authority respecting search and seizure as may be conferred by a warrant issued under section 21, and
requires the warrant to be executed within a period of time that the justice may order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a justice issues a warrant by telephone or other means of telecommunication, the following rules apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the justice must complete and sign the warrant in Form 4, noting on its face the time, date and place where it is issued;

the peace officer, on the direction of the justice, must complete, in duplicate, a facsimile of the warrant in Form 4, noting on its face the name of the justice who issued it and the time, date and place where it was issued;

the justice must, as soon as practicable after the warrant has been issued, cause the warrant to be filed with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A peace officer who executes a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication must, before entering the place or premises to be searched or as soon as practicable after entering, give a facsimile of the warrant to any person present who appears to be in control of the place or premises.

A peace officer who, in any unoccupied place or premises, executes a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication must, on entering the place or premises or as soon as practicable after entering, cause a facsimile of the warrant to be suitably affixed in a prominent place within the place or premises.

A peace officer to whom a warrant is issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication must file a written report with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant was intended for execution as soon as practicable but within a period not longer than 7 days after the warrant has been executed, and the report must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of the time and date the warrant was executed or, if the warrant was not executed, a statement of the reasons why it was not executed,
a statement of the things, if any, that were seized under the warrant and the location where they are being held, and

a statement of the things, if any, that were seized in addition to the things mentioned in the warrant and the location where they are being held, together with a statement of the peace officer's grounds for believing that those additional things had been obtained by, or used in, the commission of an offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as reasonably possible, the clerk of the court with whom a written report is filed under subsection (9) must cause the report, together with the information on oath and the warrant to which it pertains, to be brought before a justice to be dealt with under section 24.

In any proceeding in which it is material for a court to be satisfied that a search or seizure was authorized by a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication, the absence of the information on oath, transcribed and certified by the justice as to time, date and contents, or of the original warrant, signed by the justice and carrying on its face a notation of the time, date and place of issuance, is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the search or seizure was not authorized by a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication.

A person who executes a warrant under section 21 or 22 may seize, in addition to the things mentioned in the warrant, anything that on reasonable grounds the person believes has been obtained by, or has been used in, the commission of an offence.

If a thing is seized under subsection (1), as soon as reasonably possible after the seizure, the person who executed the warrant must bring the thing, or a report of the thing, before a justice to be dealt with under section 24.
For the purposes of subsection (2), the thing or report must be brought,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a warrant under section 21, before the justice who issued the warrant or another justice for the same territorial division, and
in the case of a warrant under section 22, before the justice before whom the report is brought under section 22 (10).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a thing is seized from a person by a peace officer in the execution of his or her duties otherwise than under section 21 or 22 or subsection (1) of this section, as soon as reasonably possible after the seizure, the peace officer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: return it to the person from whom it was seized, if the peace officer is satisfied that continued detention of the thing is no longer required and that there is no dispute that the person from whom it was seized is lawfully entitled to possession, or
bring the thing, or a report of the thing, before a justice to be dealt with under section 24.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and sections 24.1 and 24.2:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: relevant proceedings means a trial, inquiry or other proceeding in which the thing seized may be required;
responsible official means the prosecutor or the peace officer or other person having custody of the thing seized;
thing means anything that has been seized and is brought before a justice as referred to in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a thing or report is brought before a justice under section 21, 22 or 23, the justice must proceed as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless the prosecutor otherwise agrees, the justice must order its detention;
if paragraph (a) does not apply and the person lawfully entitled to possession is known, the justice must order its return to that person;
if neither paragraph (a) nor (b) applies, the justice must order that it be held until dealt with under section 24.2.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A thing may not be detained under subsection (2) (a) for longer than 3 months from the day of seizure unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: relevant proceedings are instituted before the end of that period, or
an order authorizing the continued detention is made on an application under subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: More than one application under subsection (5) may be made in relation to a thing, but the application must be made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a Provincial Court judge, if the total period of detention is to be longer than one year from the day of seizure if the order is made, and
to a justice in any other case.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by the responsible official made on at least 3 days' notice to the person from whom the thing was seized, the judge or justice may make an order authorizing continued detention as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an application to a justice made before the period for detention has expired, the justice may order the continued detention for a specified period if satisfied that this continued detention is warranted having regard to the nature of the investigation;

in the case of an application to a judge made before the period for detention has expired, the judge may order the continued detention for a specified period, subject to any conditions the judge considers just, if satisfied that this continued detention is warranted having regard to the nature of the investigation;

in the case of an application made after the period for detention has expired, the judge or justice may order the continued detention for a specified period, subject to any conditions the judge or justice considers just, if satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the continued detention might reasonably be required for the purpose of an investigation or relevant proceedings, and
it is in the interests of justice to make the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsection (3) or an order under subsection (5), if an application under subsection (5) has been made but is not yet decided, the period authorized for detention of the thing extends until the application is decided.

On at least 3 days' notice to the Attorney General, a person who has an interest in a thing detained under section 24 may apply to a Provincial Court judge for an order under subsection (2) that the person be permitted to examine the thing.

The judge may make an order that the applicant or a representative of the applicant be permitted to examine the thing, but must make the order on terms that the judge considers necessary or desirable to ensure that the thing to be examined is safeguarded and preserved for any purpose for which it may subsequently be required.

In the case of a thing seized that is a record, at any time while it is detained the Attorney General or responsible official may have a copy of the record made and may retain that copy even after the original is no longer detained.
A copy under subsection (3) that is certified to be a true copy by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Attorney General,
the person who made the copy, or
the person in whose presence the copy was made

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is admissible in evidence and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, has the same probative force as the original document would have had if it had been proved in the ordinary way.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order for disposition of thing seized

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided by another enactment, an order for the disposition of a thing seized may be made by application under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a Provincial Court judge, in the case of a thing ordered detained by a judge of that court, or
to a justice in any other case.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section does not apply if, under section 14.04 (1) (b) (iv) or 23.01 of the Civil Forfeiture Act, the director under that Act serves notice of forfeiture under Part 3.1 of that Act or notice of intent to commence proceedings, as the case may be, on the responsible official having custody of the thing seized, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that notice is withdrawn under section 14.08 (a) or 23.01 (4) (a) (ii) of that Act, or

in the case of notice of intent to commence proceedings, the 30 day period referred to in section 23.01 (4) (a) of that Act expires and no proceedings are commenced under section 3 of that Act in relation to the thing seized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application under this section may be made as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the person from whom the thing was seized, on at least 3 days' notice to the Attorney General, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the total period for detention under section 24 has expired, or
the judge or justice is satisfied that hardship will result unless the application is allowed to be heard earlier;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by another person claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession of the thing, at any time on at least 3 days' notice to the Attorney General and to the person from whom the thing was seized;
by a responsible official as required under subsection (3), on at least 3 days' notice to the person from whom the thing was seized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless an application is made under section 24 (5) (c), the responsible official must make an application under this section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the responsible official determines that the continued detention of a thing seized is no longer required, or
the period for detention has expired and no proceedings have been instituted in which the thing seized may be required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), on an application under this section, the judge or justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must order the thing returned to the person from whom it was seized, if that person is lawfully entitled to its possession,
must order the thing returned to another person lawfully entitled to it, if this person is known and the person from whom the thing was seized is not lawfully entitled to its possession,

if an order cannot be made under paragraph (a) or (b) because the thing has already been forfeited and sold or otherwise dealt with under paragraph (d) such that it cannot be returned to the applicant, must order that unless otherwise provided by law the applicant be paid the proceeds of sale or the value of the thing seized, and

if an order is not made under paragraph (a) or (b), may order that the thing is forfeited to the government, to be disposed of as the Attorney General directs or otherwise dealt with in accordance with the law.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order may be made under subsection (4) only if the judge or justice is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total period for detention under section 24 has expired and relevant proceedings have not been instituted, or
the total period for detention has not expired but the continued detention of the thing seized will not be required for the purpose of an investigation or relevant proceedings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person aggrieved by an order under this section may appeal the order to the Supreme Court and, for the purposes of the appeal, sections 103 to 114 apply.
Despite anything in this section, a thing must not be returned, forfeited or disposed of under an order under subsection (4) until the later of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 30 days after the order is made under subsection (4);
if the order under subsection (4) is appealed, 30 days after the decision on the appeal has been given.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section does not apply if, in relation to a thing seized, proceedings are commenced under section 3 of the Civil Forfeiture Act or the property is forfeited and disposed of by the director under Part 3.1 of that Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to lay information or complaint

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may, on reasonable and probable grounds,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lay an information before a justice

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that any person, being within the jurisdiction of that justice, has committed or is suspected of having committed an offence or act for which the person is liable by law, on conviction, to be imprisoned, fined or otherwise punished, or

that any person has committed or is suspected of having committed within British Columbia an offence or act for which the person is liable by law, on conviction, to be imprisoned, fined or otherwise punished, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a complaint to a justice in relation to any matter on which the justice has authority by law to make an order for the payment of money or otherwise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The information or complaint may be in Form 2 or of similar effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Justice to hear informant or witnesses and issue a summons or warrant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who receives an information must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear and consider without the necessity of notice to any other person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the allegations of the informant, and
the evidence of witnesses if the justice considers it desirable or necessary, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the justice considers that a case for doing so is made out, issue a summons or warrant to compel the defendant to attend before the justice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who hears the evidence of a witness under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: take the evidence on oath, and
have the evidence taken in accordance with section 540 of the Criminal Code, insofar as that section is capable of being applied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice must not sign a summons or warrant in blank.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A summons may be in one of the prescribed forms and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be directed to the defendant,
set out briefly the offence in respect of which the defendant is charged, and
require the defendant to appear at a time and place stated in the summons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), a summons must be served by a peace officer or enforcement officer, who must deliver it personally to the person to whom it is directed, or, if that person cannot conveniently be found, must leave it for the person at the person's last or usual residence with an occupant of it who appears to be at least 16 years of age.

For the purposes of the service of a summons in respect of an alleged offence under a bylaw of a municipality, a peace officer includes a bylaw enforcement officer appointed under section 36 of the Police Act.

A summons in respect of an alleged offence under a bylaw of a municipality or regional district may be served in the manner set out in subsection (1) by a person appointed for that purpose by the council of the municipality or the board of the regional district.
For the purposes of this section, a person appointed under subsection (3) has the legal status of a peace officer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service on a corporation or municipality

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if the defendant is a corporation, the summons must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by delivering it to a director, or to a manager, secretary or other executive officer of the corporation or of a branch of it, or on the attorney of an extraprovincial company, or

if after hearing evidence that a person referred to in paragraph (a) cannot be conveniently found, a justice so orders, by leaving it at, or mailing it by registered post addressed to, the registered or principal office of the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the defendant is a municipality or regional district, the summons may be served by delivering it

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of the City of Vancouver, to the mayor or city clerk,
in the case of another municipality, to the mayor or in accordance with section 159 [notice to municipality] of the Community Charter, and
in the case of a regional district, to the chair of the regional district or in accordance with section 246 [giving notice to regional districts] of the Local Government Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is any reference in this Act to service of a summons, appearance notice or promise to appear or to a summons, appearance notice or promise to appear being served, the reference must be read as a reference to service of the summons, appearance notice or promise to appear or a copy of it, and a summons, appearance notice or promise to appear is sufficiently served if a copy of it is served.

If a copy of a summons, appearance notice or promise to appear is served, the certificate referred to in section 31 (1) (b) may be endorsed on another copy of, or on, the summons, appearance notice or promise to appear.
Service of a summons, violation ticket, appearance notice and promise to appear may be proved by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the oral evidence given under oath of a person who served it,

the certificate of service, other than an eCertificate of service, of a person who served the summons, violation ticket, appearance notice or promise to appear if the certificate is endorsed on a copy of the document that was served, or
the eCertificate of service of a person who served a violation ticket that is an eTicket.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The certificate referred to in subsection (1) (b) is proof of the authority of the person who signed it.

When a certificate of service referred to in subsection (1) (b) or (c) is completed for the purposes of proving service of a violation ticket, the certificate must be sent to the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia.

The Insurance Corporation of British Columbia may electronically convert from paper format to electronic format or store or send in electronic format a certificate of service of a violation ticket issued in respect of an offence under section 83.1 (2) or (2.1) of the Motor Vehicle Act.
If the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia has stored a certificate of service of a violation ticket in electronic format under subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the corporation may provide the certificate of service by reproducing it in electronic format or paper format, or on a record that enables the information to be subsequently displayed or immediately accessible in visible form, and
the reproduction referred to in paragraph (a) has the same effect for all purposes as an original of the certificate of service, if the reproduction

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is certified in writing by an officer of the corporation as being a true reproduction of all the information on the certificate of service, or
contains a statement that it is an authentic reproduction of all the information on a certificate of service stored in a database in electronic format by the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, an eCertificate of service is a type of certificate of service created as an electronic digital record to be used to prove service of eTickets.
An eCertificate of service includes a printout or display, in the prescribed form, that is produced from the digital record of the certificate.

A printout or display of the digital record of an eCertificate of service containing a statement that it is an authentic printout or display produced from the digital record is conclusive proof of that fact.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a document has been served in any manner, including electronically, the court may make an order validating the service if the court is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the document came to the notice of the person to be served, or
the document was served in such a manner that it would have come to the notice of the person to be served except for the person's own attempts to evade service.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A warrant or summons authorized by this Act may be issued or executed on a Sunday or statutory holiday.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Copy of a warrant to be served
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a warrant is issued in the first instance for the arrest of a defendant, a copy of it must be served on the person who is arrested under it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Contents of a warrant to arrest

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A warrant may be in Form 5 and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: name or describe the defendant,
set out briefly the offence in respect of which the defendant is charged, and

order that the defendant be arrested and brought before the justice who issued the warrant or before another justice who has jurisdiction in the same territorial division, to answer to the charge and be further dealt with according to law.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A warrant remains in force until it is executed and need not be made returnable at any particular time.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A warrant must be signed by a justice and may be directed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a peace officer by name,
to a peace officer by name and all other peace officers in the territorial jurisdiction of the justice, or
generally to all peace officers within the territorial jurisdiction of the justice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Summons not to prevent a warrant
bcl:section.bcl:text: A justice may issue a warrant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in Form 5 for the arrest of a defendant even if a summons has already been issued to require the appearance of the defendant, or
in one of the prescribed forms, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: service of a summons is proved and the defendant does not appear,
it appears that a summons cannot be served because the defendant is evading service, or
service of an appearance notice or promise to appear is proved and the defendant does not attend court in accordance with the appearance notice or promise to appear.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A warrant may be executed by arresting the defendant wherever the defendant is found within the territorial jurisdiction of the justice who issued the warrant.

A warrant may be executed by a person who is the peace officer named in the warrant or one of the peace officers to whom it is directed, whether or not the place in which the warrant is to be executed is in the territory for which the person is a peace officer.
In this section, officer in charge means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the officer in command of the police force or police department, or of the designated policing unit or designated law enforcement unit as those terms are defined in section 1 of the Police Act, who is responsible for the lockup or other place to which a defendant is taken after arrest, or

a peace officer designated by the officer referred to in paragraph (a) for this section who is in charge of the lockup or other place at the time the defendant is taken to that place to be detained in custody.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a justice issues a warrant under this Act for the arrest of a defendant, the justice may authorize the release of the defendant under subsection (3) by making an endorsement on the warrant in Form 17.

If a person who has been arrested with a warrant issued under this Act is taken into custody, the officer in charge may, if the warrant has been endorsed by a justice under subsection (2), release the defendant on the defendant giving his or her promise to appear.

If an enactment provides for the arrest of a person without the issuing of a warrant for the person's arrest and the person is taken into custody, the officer in charge may, despite the enactment under which the arrest is made, release the person on the person giving his or her promise to appear.
A promise to appear must be in a prescribed form.
A person who fails to comply with the conditions set out in a promise to appear commits an offence.
An appearance notice may be issued by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who has a power to arrest without warrant under an enactment, and
an enforcement officer, for contravention of an enactment in respect of which the regulations allow an enforcement officer to issue an appearance notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appearance notice must be in a prescribed form.
A person who fails to comply with the conditions set out in an appearance notice commits an offence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure to procure attendance of a prisoner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person who is confined in a prison in British Columbia is required

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to stand trial for an offence to which this Act applies, or
to attend to give evidence in a proceeding to which this Act applies,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the Supreme Court or a justice may order in writing that the prisoner be brought before the justice before whom his or her attendance is required, as necessary, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant for the order sets out the facts of the case in an affidavit and produces the warrant, if any, and
the court or justice is satisfied that the ends of justice require that an order be made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order made under subsection (1) must be addressed to the person who has custody of the prisoner, and on receipt of it that person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deliver the prisoner to a person named in the order to receive the prisoner, or
bring the prisoner before the justice on payment of his or her reasonable charges for so doing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the prisoner is required as a witness, the court or justice must direct in the order the manner in which the prisoner is to be kept in custody and returned to the prison from which he or she is brought.

If the appearance of the prisoner is required for the purposes of subsection (1) (a), the court or justice must give appropriate directions in the order with respect to the manner in which the prisoner is to be returned if he or she is acquitted of the charge against him or her.
Section 83 applies if a prisoner to whom this section applies is convicted and sentenced to imprisonment by the justice.

If a warrant for the arrest of a defendant cannot be executed in accordance with section 37, a justice in whose jurisdiction the defendant is, or is believed to be, must, on application and on proof on oath, or by affidavit, of the signature of the justice who issued the warrant, authorize the execution of the warrant in his or her jurisdiction by making an endorsement, which may be in Form 16, on the warrant.

An endorsement made on a warrant under subsection (1) is sufficient authority to the peace officers to whom it was originally directed and to all peace officers in the territorial jurisdiction of the justice by whom it is endorsed to execute the warrant and to take the defendant before the justice who issued the warrant or before another justice for the same territorial division.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless section 40 applies, sections 43 to 52 apply if a person is required to attend to give evidence in a proceeding to which this Act applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Subpoena or warrant may be issued

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is likely to give material evidence in a proceeding to which this Act applies, a subpoena may be issued requiring that person to attend to give evidence.
If it is made to appear that a person who is likely to give material evidence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: will not attend in response to a subpoena, if a subpoena is issued, or
is evading service of a subpoena,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: a court or justice having power to issue a subpoena to require the attendance of that person to give evidence may issue a warrant in Form 8 to cause that person to be arrested and to be brought to give evidence.
Unless subsection (2) (a) applies, a warrant in Form 8 must not be issued unless a subpoena has first been issued.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements for issuing subpoena or warrant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is required to attend to give evidence in proceedings over which a justice has jurisdiction, a subpoena directed to that person must be issued

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by a justice if the person whose attendance is required is in British Columbia, or
out of the Supreme Court if the person whose attendance is required is not in British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A subpoena must not be issued under subsection (1) (b) except under an order of the court made on application by a party to the proceedings.
A subpoena or warrant that is issued by a court must be under the seal of the court and must be signed by the court or by the clerk of the court.
A subpoena or warrant that is issued by a justice must be signed by the justice.
A subpoena may be in Form 7.

A subpoena must require the person to whom it is directed to attend at a time and place to be stated in the subpoena to give evidence and, if required, to bring with him or her any writings that the person has in his or her possession or under his or her control relating to the subject matter of the proceedings.
A person who is served with a subpoena must attend and remain in attendance throughout the proceedings, unless excused by the justice.
Subject to subsection (2), a subpoena must be served in accordance with section 28.
A subpoena issued under section 44 (1) (b) must be served personally on the person to whom it is directed.
Service of a subpoena may be proved by the affidavit of the person who effected service.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A subpoena issued by a justice has effect anywhere in British Columbia.
Subject to section 49 (3), a warrant issued by a justice may be executed anywhere in British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is bound by a recognizance to give evidence in any proceedings, a justice who is satisfied, on information being made before the justice in writing and under oath, that the person is about to abscond or has absconded, may issue a warrant, in Form 9, directing a peace officer to arrest that person and to bring the person before the justice before whom the person is bound to appear.
Section 41 applies to a warrant issued under this section.
A person who is arrested under this section is entitled, on request, to receive a copy of the information on which the warrant for the arrest was issued.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warrant when witness does not attend

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person who has been served with a subpoena to give evidence in a proceeding does not attend or remain in attendance, the justice before whom that person was required to attend may issue or cause to be issued a warrant, in Form 8, for the arrest of that person, if it is established that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subpoena has been served in accordance with this Act, and
the person is likely to give material evidence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person who has been bound by a recognizance to attend to give evidence in any proceeding does not attend or does not remain in attendance, the court or justice before whom that person was bound to attend may issue or cause to be issued a warrant, in Form 8, for the arrest of that person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order where witness arrested under warrant
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person is brought before a justice under a warrant issued under section 43 (2), or under section 49 or 50, the justice may order that the person be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: detained in custody, or
released on recognizance, in Form 18, with or without sureties,

bcl:section.bcl:text: to appear and give evidence when required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who, being required by law to attend or remain in attendance to give evidence, fails, without lawful excuse, to attend or remain in attendance accordingly is guilty of contempt of court.
A judge of the Provincial Court may deal summarily with a person who is guilty of contempt of court under this section.
A person who is guilty of contempt of court under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is liable to a fine of $100, or to imprisonment for 90 days or to both, and
may be ordered to pay the costs incidental to the service and execution of the subpoena and warrant and to his or her detention, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A conviction under this section may be in Form 21, and a warrant of committal in respect of a conviction under this section may be in Form 14.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 2.1 of the Provincial Court Act, every justice has the same power and authority to preserve order in a court over which he or she presides as may be exercised by the Supreme Court.

The room or place in which the justice sits to hear and try a complaint or information is deemed to be an open and public court to which the public generally may have access so far as it can conveniently contain them.

When resistance is offered to the execution of a summons, warrant of execution or other process issued by a justice, the justice may enforce the execution of it by the means provided by the law for enforcing the execution of the process of other courts in similar cases.

If the defendant appears for the trial and the prosecutor, having had notice, does not appear, the justice may dismiss the information or may adjourn the trial to another time on terms the justice considers proper.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appearance of the prosecutor and defendant or counsel

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the prosecutor and defendant appear, the justice must proceed to hold the trial.

A defendant may appear personally or by counsel or agent, but the justice may require the defendant to appear personally, and may, if the justice thinks fit, issue a warrant, in Form 5, for the arrest of the defendant and adjourn the trial to await his or her appearance under the warrant.

If the defendant is a corporation, it must appear by counsel or agent, and if it does not appear, the justice may, on proof of service of the summons, proceed without further notice to hold the trial.

bcl:section.bcl:text: When the defendant appears, the substance of the information must be stated to the defendant, and the defendant must be asked

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the defendant pleads guilty or not guilty to the information, if the proceedings are in respect of an offence that is punishable on conviction, or
whether the defendant has cause to show why an order should not be made against him or her, in proceedings where a justice is authorized by law to make an order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Conviction or order if charge admitted
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the defendant pleads guilty or does not show sufficient cause why an order should not be made against him or her the justice must convict the defendant or make an order against the defendant accordingly.
