If the defendant pleads not guilty or states that he or she has cause to show why an order should not be made against him or her the justice must proceed with the trial, and must take the evidence of witnesses for the prosecutor and the defendant in the same manner, as nearly as may be, as evidence is taken on a preliminary inquiry under Part XVIII of the Criminal Code.
Before or during the trial, a justice who is satisfied that the ends of justice require it, may direct that the defendant be tried separately on one or more of the counts in the information.

If a justice is satisfied that one or more informations or violation tickets, or a combination of them, relate to the same incident and that the interests of justice require it, the justice may, before or during trial, direct that the defendant be tried on one or more of the informations or violation tickets, or a combination of them, at the same time.
A defendant may admit any fact alleged against the defendant for the purpose of dispensing with the proof of it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An enforcement officer may appear as, and may exercise the powers and perform the functions of, a prosecutor in relation to a violation ticket under this Act whether or not he or she is a member of the Law Society of British Columbia.
Section 15 (1) of the Legal Profession Act does not apply in respect of anything authorized under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The prosecutor is entitled personally to conduct his or her case, and the defendant is entitled to make a full answer and defence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The prosecutor or defendant may examine and cross examine witnesses personally or by counsel or agent.
A witness must be examined on oath or affirmation.
The justice has full power and authority to administer to a witness the usual oath or affirmation.
A justice who, in a proceeding, is exercising jurisdiction under the Provincial Court Act may, at any stage of the proceeding, exercise that jurisdiction in the absence of a prosecutor.
If a justice is exercising the jurisdiction referred to in subsection (1) in the absence of a prosecutor,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 56 does not apply,
the justice may, under section 67 (1), adjourn the trial, and
section 69 applies only if the adjournment was made during a trial where a prosecutor had appeared.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may in his or her discretion, before or during a trial, adjourn the trial.
The parties to a trial adjourned under subsection (1) must be notified of the time and place appointed for their next appearance before the court.
For the purpose of giving notice under subsection (1.1) in relation to a violation ticket, section 15 (6) applies.
If the justice adjourns a trial, the justice may, on condition that the defendant appear at the time and place set for resumption of the trial,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit the defendant to be at large,
commit the defendant by warrant, in Form 10, to a prison in the territorial division for which the justice has jurisdiction, or to any other safe custody the justice thinks fit, or
discharge the defendant on the defendant's recognizance, in Form 18

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: with or without sureties, or
on depositing a sum of money the justice directs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the defendant does not appear at the time and place appointed for the trial, and service of the summons within a reasonable period before the appearance was required is proved, or if the defendant does not appear for the resumption of a trial that has been adjourned in accordance with section 67, the justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed to hear and determine the proceedings in the absence of the defendant as fully and effectually as if the defendant had appeared, or
if the justice thinks fit, issue a warrant in a prescribed form or Form 6 for the arrest of the defendant, and adjourn the trial to await the defendant's appearance to it.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the prosecutor does not appear at the time and place appointed for the resumption of an adjourned trial, the justice may dismiss the information, with or without costs.

If the justice is of the opinion, supported by the evidence of at least one medical practitioner or nurse practitioner, that there is reason to believe that the defendant is mentally ill, the justice, at any time before convicting the defendant or making an order against the defendant or dismissing the information, may, by order in writing, remand the defendant to the custody that the justice directs for observation for a period of not longer than 30 days.

If a person gives security by a recognizance or is bound by a recognizance to appear before a justice for any purpose, sections 762 to 773 of the Criminal Code apply, with the necessary changes and so far as applicable, to the recognizance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supreme Court may grant or vary bail
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Supreme Court may, on application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: admit the defendant to bail if bail has been refused by a justice, or
vary the amount of bail set by a justice.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2012-1-3.]
When the justice has heard the prosecutor, defendant and witnesses, the justice must, after considering the matter,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: convict the defendant,
make an order against the defendant, or
dismiss the information.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a defendant is convicted of an offence for which a greater punishment may be imposed by reason of previous convictions, a greater punishment must not be imposed on the defendant for that reason, unless the prosecutor satisfies the justice that the defendant, before making his or her plea, was notified that a greater punishment would be sought for that reason.

If a defendant is convicted of an offence for which a greater punishment may be imposed by reason of previous convictions, the justice must, on application by the prosecutor, and on being satisfied that the defendant was notified in accordance with subsection (1), ask the defendant whether the defendant was previously convicted, and if the defendant does not admit that he or she was previously convicted, evidence of previous convictions may be adduced.

A justice who holds a trial under section 68 may, if the justice convicts the defendant, make inquiries with respect to previous convictions, whether or not the defendant was notified that a greater punishment would be sought because of them.
Under this section, a previous conviction may be proved in the manner prescribed by section 667 of the Criminal Code.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a defendant is convicted or if an order is made against the defendant,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a minute or memorandum of the conviction or order may be made, without fee, but whether or not a minute or memorandum is made, the conviction or order must be drawn up by the justice in Form 19 or 20, and
the justice must issue a warrant of committal in Form 11 or 12, and section 41 applies to the warrant of committal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disposal of penalties when joint offenders
bcl:section.bcl:text: If several persons join in committing the same offence, and on conviction each is adjudged to pay an amount to a person aggrieved, no more must be paid to that person than an amount equal to the value of the property destroyed or injured or the amount of the injury done, together with costs, if any, and the residue of the amount adjudged to be paid must be applied in the manner in which other penalties imposed by law are directed to be applied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the justice dismisses an information, the justice may, if requested by the defendant, draw up an order of dismissal, and must give to the defendant a certified copy of the order of dismissal.
A copy of an order of dismissal, certified in accordance with subsection (1), is, without further proof, a bar to any subsequent proceedings against the defendant in respect of the same cause.
The justice may, in his or her discretion, award and order costs the justice considers reasonable and not inconsistent with the fees established by section 80 to be paid

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the informant by the defendant, if the justice convicts or makes an order against the defendant, or
to the defendant by the informant, if the justice dismisses an information.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1) must be set out in the conviction, order, or order of dismissal.
Costs awarded and ordered to be paid by a person under this section are deemed to be all or part, as the case may be, of a fine imposed against the person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The fees and allowances mentioned in the tariff to this Act, and no others, are the fees and allowances that may be taken or allowed in proceedings before justices under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, court means the Provincial Court.

If a person is convicted of an offence under a prescribed enactment, the court may order that the defendant is liable, after review and the filing of a certificate under this section, for the costs of the investigation into the offence.
The prosecutor may prepare a certificate setting out the costs of the investigation, including the cost to the government of any fees paid to experts, investigators and witnesses.
The prosecutor may apply to a registrar of the Supreme Court to have the certificate reviewed and, on the review, the registrar must assess the costs that are payable under subsection (2).
The registrar may vary the costs if he or she considers that they are unreasonable or not related to the investigation.
The Supreme Court Civil Rules apply to the review of a certificate under this section as though it were a review of disbursements under those rules.

After the review, the certificate of the registrar may be filed in the court and may be enforced as if it were an order of the court requiring the person convicted to pay the amount of costs in the certificate to the government.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations for the purposes of this section including regulations that prescribe an enactment for the purposes of subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Imprisonment for default of payment of fine

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (7), but despite any other provision of this Act, any other Act, regulation, municipal bylaw or order made by a justice, a justice must not, except under the Small Claims Act, order that a person be imprisoned merely because he or she defaults in paying a fine.

If a justice imposes a fine authorized by this or any other Act, the justice, despite this Act or the Act under which the fine is imposed, may order that the fine and the victim surcharge levy that is, under section 8.1 of the Victims of Crime Act, to be paid with that fine, be paid

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (3), at once, or
at a time, in instalments and subject to terms and conditions the justice considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice must not make an order under subsection (2) (a) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the justice is satisfied that the person against whom the fine is imposed has sufficient means and ability to enable the person to pay the fine and the victim surcharge levy that is, under section 8.1 of the Victims of Crime Act, to be paid with that fine, at once,
on being asked by the justice whether he or she desires time for payment, the person against whom the fine is imposed does not request time, or

the justice has a special reason, which the justice must give orally or in writing, for requiring that the fine and the victim surcharge levy that is, under section 8.1 of the Victims of Crime Act, to be paid with that fine, be paid at once.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making an order under subsection (2) (b), the justice must consider any representations made by the person against whom the fine is imposed, and must not make the first instalment payable within 14 days after the date of the order.
A justice, on application made at any time by the person against whom a fine is imposed, may amend or vary an order made under subsection (2) (b).
If a person fails to pay

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a fine and victim surcharge levy in accordance with an order made under subsection (2), or
a ticketed amount payable as a result of the person being found guilty of or being deemed to have pleaded guilty to the contravention of an enactment alleged in a violation ticket,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: a certificate of a person designated in the regulations may be filed with the Supreme Court or Provincial Court stating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date of the conviction or the deemed guilty plea, as the case may be, and the amount of the fine and victim surcharge levy or of the ticketed amount, as the case may be,
the name of the person required to pay the fine and victim surcharge levy or the ticketed amount, as the case may be,
the date on which the fine and victim surcharge levy or the ticketed amount, as the case may be, was payable,
the amount of the fine and victim surcharge levy or of the ticketed amount, as the case may be, remaining unpaid, and
the amount of interest payable under section 82.1 with respect to the unpaid amount of the fine and victim surcharge levy or of the ticketed amount, as the case may be.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A certificate filed with the Supreme Court or Provincial Court under subsection (6) has the same effect, and proceedings may be taken by a person or a class of persons designated by the Attorney General, as if it were a judgment of the Supreme Court for the recovery of a debt in the amounts referred to in subsection (6) (f) and (g) against the person named in the certificate.
A certificate may not be filed under subsection (6)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with respect to a fine and victim surcharge levy payable in accordance with an order made under subsection (2), more than 10 years after the day on which the order is made, and

with respect to a ticketed amount referred to in subsection (6) (b), more than 10 years after the day on which the person is found guilty of or is deemed to have pleaded guilty to the contravention of an enactment alleged in the violation ticket.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an enactment prescribes different degrees or kinds of punishment in respect of an offence, the punishment to be imposed is, subject to the limitations prescribed in the enactment, in the discretion of the justice who convicts a person who commits the offence.

If an enactment prescribes punishment in respect of an offence, the punishment to be imposed is, subject to the limitations prescribed in the enactment, in the discretion of the justice who convicts a person who commits the offence, but no punishment is a minimum punishment unless it is declared to be a minimum punishment.
If a defendant is convicted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: while under sentence for an offence, and a term of imprisonment is imposed, or
of more than one offence before the same justice at the same sitting, and the justice imposes terms of imprisonment for the respective offences,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the justice who convicts the defendant may direct that the terms of imprisonment are to be served one after the other.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Punishment only after conviction and only as prescribed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an enactment creates an offence and authorizes a punishment to be imposed in respect of it,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person is deemed to be not guilty of that offence until convicted of it, and
a person who is convicted of that offence is not liable to punishment in respect of it other than the punishment prescribed by this Act or by the enactment that creates the offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Everyone is a party to an offence who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: actually commits it,
does or omits to do anything for the purpose of aiding a person to commit it, or
abets a person in committing it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person counsels or procures another person to be a party to an offence and that other person is afterwards a party to that offence, the person who counselled or procured is a party to that offence, even if the offence was committed in a way different from that which was counselled or procured.

Everyone who counsels or procures another person to be a party to an offence is a party to every offence that the other person commits, in consequence of the counselling or procuring, that the person who counselled or procured knew or ought to have known was likely to be committed in consequence of the counselling or procuring.
A sentence commences when it is imposed, unless a relevant enactment otherwise provides or the justice or the court appealed to otherwise orders.
The time during which a convicted person is at large on bail does not count as part of any term of imprisonment imposed as a result of the person's conviction.

Despite subsection (1), a term of imprisonment, whether imposed by the justice or the court appealed to, commences or is deemed to be resumed, as the case requires, on the day on which the convicted person is arrested and taken into custody under the sentence.

If a defendant who is convicted of an offence is sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 90 days or less and the justice considers it just and reasonable to do so, the justice may, by order, direct that the defendant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve the sentence intermittently at the times specified by the justice in the order, and
comply with the conditions in a probation order

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: when the defendant is not in custody during the period the sentence is being served, and
on the defendant's release from custody after the defendant completes the sentence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A defendant who is ordered to serve a sentence of imprisonment intermittently may, on giving notice to a prosecutor, apply to a justice for an order allowing the defendant to serve the sentence on consecutive days.

If a justice imposes a term of imprisonment on a defendant who is subject to an intermittent sentence in respect of another offence, the unexpired portion of the intermittent sentence must be served on consecutive days, unless the justice orders otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court may impose a lesser fine

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other section of this Act or any other Act, in determining the fine to be imposed on conviction, the justice must consider the means and ability of the defendant to pay the fine, and, if the justice is of the opinion that the defendant is unable to pay the amount of the fine that the justice would otherwise impose, the justice may impose a fine in a lesser amount that the justice considers appropriate.
If a minimum fine is established under the Motor Vehicle Act for contravention of a provision of that Act, a justice must not impose under subsection (1) a fine of less than the minimum established.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a defendant is convicted of an offence, the justice, having regard to the age, character and background of the defendant, the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding the commission of the offence, may, by order,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: instead of sentencing the defendant to punishment, suspend the passing of sentence and direct that the defendant be released on the conditions in a probation order, or
in addition to imposing on the defendant a fine or term of imprisonment, direct that the defendant comply with the conditions in a probation order.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The justice must include, as conditions in a probation order, that the defendant do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep the peace and be of good behaviour;
appear before the court as and when required to do so by a justice;
notify the justice or a person designated by the justice

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in advance of any change in the defendant's name or address, and
promptly of any change in the defendant's employment or occupation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The justice may include, as additional conditions in a probation order, that the defendant must comply with one or more of the following, as specified in the order:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant must report to a probation officer or other person designated by the justice

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within 2 business days after the probation order is made, unless a longer period is specified by the justice, and
after reporting under subparagraph (i), at the times and in the manner directed by the probation officer or designated person;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant must be under the supervision of the probation officer or designated person referred to in paragraph (a);
the defendant must not possess or consume

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: alcohol or other intoxicating substances, or
a controlled substance, as defined in the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (Canada), except in accordance with a medical prescription;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant must not own, possess or carry a weapon;
the defendant must provide for the support or care of a spouse or other dependants;
the defendant must perform community service;
if the defendant agrees and is accepted into the program, the defendant must actively participate in a treatment or other program approved by the government;
the defendant must make restitution or reparation for any loss or damage suffered as a result of the commission of the offence;
the defendant must not make contact with a person or may have only limited contact with a person;
the defendant must not be present at a place or premises;
the defendant must provide a written apology;
the defendant must comply with any other reasonable conditions the justice considers appropriate to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: protect the public,
prevent similar unlawful conduct by the defendant, or
contribute to the rehabilitation of the defendant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Term and form of probation order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A probation order may be kept in force for a term not exceeding 2 years.
The justice who makes a probation order must specify the term of the probation order.
A probation order may be in Form 25.
The justice who makes a probation order must take reasonable steps to ensure that the defendant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receives a copy of the order,
receives an explanation of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the mandatory and optional conditions in the order;
the process under section 89.5 for making changes to the order;
the consequences under section 89.6 for failing to comply with a probation order, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: understands the order and the explanations given under paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, a failure to comply with subsection (1) does not affect the validity of a probation order.
A defendant, probation officer or prosecutor, with notice to the others, may apply to a justice for an order under subsection (3).
On an application under subsection (1), the justice must require the defendant to appear before the justice.
After hearing from the defendant and one or both of the probation officer and the prosecutor, the justice may, by order, do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the justice considers it appropriate because of a change in circumstances,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: change an optional condition in the probation order,
add an optional condition to the probation order, or
remove an optional condition from the probation order;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: relieve the defendant from compliance with an optional condition in the probation order, either absolutely or on terms or for a period the justice considers appropriate;
terminate the probation order or decrease the period for which the probation order is to be kept in force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the justice makes an order under subsection (3), the justice must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: endorse the probation order accordingly, and
take reasonable steps to ensure that the defendant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is informed of any changes made to the probation order under subsection (3) (a) to (c), and
receives a copy of the endorsed probation order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Failure to comply with probation order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A defendant who is bound by a probation order commits an offence if the defendant, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a condition in the probation order.
A defendant who is charged with an offence under subsection (1) may be tried and punished by any justice having jurisdiction to try that offence in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the place where the offence is alleged to have been committed, or
the place where the defendant is found, arrested or in custody.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, police officer means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a special provincial constable, as defined in the Police Act,
a designated constable, as defined in the Police Act,
an officer, member or constable of the provincial police force,
an officer, member or constable of a municipal police force in the Province, or
a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A police officer may arrest without warrant a person whom the police officer believes on reasonable and probable grounds is committing an offence under section 89.6.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of provisions in section 732.2 of Criminal Code
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 732.2 (1) and (2) (a) of the Criminal Code applies, with the necessary changes and so far as applicable, to a probation order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional punishment for breach of probation order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice who meets the requirements under subsection (2) may make an order under subsection (3) if a defendant who is bound by a probation order is convicted of an offence, including an offence under section 89.6, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant has elected not to appeal against the conviction for that offence,
the time limit for bringing an appeal against the conviction for that offence has expired and the defendant has not appealed against the conviction, or
the defendant has appealed against the conviction for that offence and the appeal has been dismissed or abandoned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may make an order under subsection (3) only if the justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is the same justice who made the probation order, or
has jurisdiction in the territorial division in which the probation order was made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the requirements under subsections (1) and (2) are met, then, in addition to any punishment that may be imposed for the offence, the justice may, by order,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: change an optional condition in the probation order,
add an optional condition to the probation order,
remove an optional condition from the probation order,
extend the period, by not more than one year, for which the probation order is to be kept in force,
terminate the probation order, or
if the probation order was made under section 89 (a),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: revoke the probation order, and
impose any sentence that could have been imposed if the passing of sentence had not been suspended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a justice makes an order under subsection (3), the justice must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: endorse the probation order accordingly, and
take reasonable steps to ensure that the defendant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is informed of any changes made to the probation order under subsection (3) (a) to (f), and
receives a copy of the endorsed probation order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a peace officer finds, in a place to which the public has access, a person who is in a state of intoxication, the peace officer may take that person into custody.
If it appears to the peace officer that the person may be in need of remedial treatment because of the use of alcohol, the peace officer must, within 24 hours, take the person to a physician.
If the peace officer does not act under subsection (2), the person in custody must be released

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on recovering sufficient capacity to remove himself or herself without danger to himself or herself or others, or causing a nuisance, or
if application is made sooner by an adult who appears to be capable of taking charge of the person, into the charge of the applicant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a physician is satisfied that a person brought to him or her under subsection (2) is in need of treatment because of the excessive use of alcohol and that no arrangements have been made for the voluntary treatment of the person, or, if made, are not likely to be adhered to by the person,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the physician may give a certificate to that effect, and the person may be taken to, examined, treated and detained in, an institution for the treatment and rehabilitation of chronic alcoholics, or to a psychiatric unit or observation unit, within the meaning of the Mental Health Act, and
an application may be made for a confirming order under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the physician is not satisfied that the person is in need of treatment under subsection (4), the person must be released at once.

A person taken to an institution or unit under the authority of a certificate given under subsection (4) must not be detained there for more than 72 hours unless the person's continued detention is authorized by a confirming order.
Subsections (1), (2) and (3) apply only to those portions of British Columbia and to those classes of persons that the Lieutenant Governor in Council designates.
In this section, confirming order means an order made under subsection (4).
An application for a confirming order may be made to a justice exercising jurisdiction at the place

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: where the person was taken into custody,
at which the person is detained, or
where the person has his or her home.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The application may be heard and determined, and adjourned, even if the person has been released from the place where he or she was detained under the authority of a certificate given under section 91 (4).

If, after hearing the evidence of a physician who has examined the person and any other evidence of the person's addiction to, or use of, alcohol, and any evidence of the person concerned, the justice is satisfied that the person concerned is in need of treatment and rehabilitation as provided for chronic alcoholics, and that no firm arrangements have been made for the voluntary treatment of the person or, if made, are not likely to be adhered to by the person, the justice may make an order that, for an indeterminate term not exceeding 12 months, the person attend at, or be detained in, an institution where treatment is provided for chronic alcoholics.

If the justice dismisses an application for a confirming order before the expiration of the period of 72 hours referred to in section 91 (6), the dismissal does not, unless the justice makes an order to that effect, impair the authority of the certificate, and the person may continue to be detained as provided in the certificate until the expiration of the period of 72 hours.

A copy of an order for detention made under subsection (4) must be directed to the director of correction, who must, if space is available, make arrangements for the detention of the person named in the order at an institution where treatment and rehabilitation is provided for chronic alcoholics, and, if the person named is detained in a psychiatric unit or observation unit, he or she must be transferred accordingly.

If detention is ordered under subsection (4), pending transfer to the place of detention, the person may be detained in a common jail or lockup, and the time during which a person is detained must be deducted from the indeterminate term imposed under this section.

Despite this Act, the chief probation officer may, before the expiration of the term of attendance or detention ordered under subsection (3), discharge the person from attendance or detention on terms and conditions that the chief probation officer may, in his or her discretion, impose for the unexpired portion of that term.

If the chief probation officer certifies in writing that there has been a breach of any term or condition imposed by him or her under section 92 (8), the chief probation officer may, by signing a warrant, authorize the apprehension of the person by a peace officer.

On apprehension, the person must be brought before a justice, who, on being satisfied that the person has failed to observe a term or condition imposed by the chief probation officer, may order that the person be detained in a place named in the order for the balance of the term ordered under section 92 (4), unless sooner discharged by the chief probation officer on terms and conditions specified by him or her.

The production of a document purporting to be signed by the chief probation officer, and to be his or her certificate under subsection (1), is evidence of a breach referred to in the certificate and of the authority for the detention of the person named in it.

If a person, without authority, absents himself or herself from a place of detention, or, if his or her absence is authorized under section 92 (8), the person fails to return to the place of detention when instructed by the chief probation officer to do so, the person may be apprehended, with or without a warrant, by a peace officer and returned to the place of detention.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2007-8-57.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A peace officer or other person to whom a warrant of committal authorized by this or any other Act or law is directed must convey the person named or described in the warrant to the jail or other prison mentioned in the warrant and deliver the person, together with the warrant, to the keeper of the jail or prison, who must then give to the peace officer or other person who delivers the prisoner a receipt, in Form 24, setting out the state and condition of the prisoner when delivered into his or her custody.

It is not necessary to give a receipt to a peace officer or other person delivering a prisoner to the custody of the keeper or other person in charge of a municipal lockup or of a prison which is not a common jail of any county.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Originating document must contain substance of evidence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An information, complaint, warrant, conviction or other proceeding under this Act must in general apply to a single transaction, and must contain, and is sufficient if it contains in substance, a statement that the defendant committed an offence or act specified in the proceeding and punishable on summary conviction.
The statement referred to in subsection (1) may be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in popular language without technical averments or allegations of matters that are not essential to be proved,
in the words of the enactment that describes the offence or declares the matters charged to be an offence or act punishable on summary conviction, or
in words that are sufficient to give to the defendant notice of the offence with which the defendant is charged.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An information must contain sufficient detail of the circumstances of the alleged offence to give to the defendant reasonable information with respect to the act or omission to be proved against the defendant and to identify the transaction referred to, but otherwise the absence or insufficiency of details does not vitiate the information.

An information may refer to any section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph or clause of the enactment that creates the offence charged, and for determining whether an information is sufficient, consideration must be given to any such reference.
Nothing in this Act relating to matters that do not render an information insufficient is deemed to restrict or limit the application of this section.

No information, complaint, warrant, conviction or other proceeding under this Act is insufficient because of the absence of details if, in the opinion of the justice, the information otherwise fulfills the requirements of section 96.
Without restricting subsection (1), no information is insufficient merely because it fails to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: name the person injured or intended or attempted to be injured,
name the person who owns or has a special property or interest in property mentioned in the information,
specify the means by which the alleged offence was committed,
name or describe with precision any person, place or thing, or
if the consent of a person, official or authority is required before proceedings may be instituted for an offence, state that the consent has been obtained.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The justice may, if satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order that a particular, further describing any matter relevant to the proceedings, be furnished to the defendant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Burden on defendant to prove an exception

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No exception, exemption, proviso, excuse or qualification prescribed by law is required to be set out or negatived in an information.

The burden of proving that an exception, exemption, proviso, excuse or qualification prescribed by law operates in favour of the defendant is on the defendant, and the prosecutor is not required, except by way of rebuttal, to prove that the exception, exemption, proviso, excuse or qualification does not operate in favour of the defendant, whether or not it is set out in the information.

If it appears that the defendant has done any act or been guilty of any omission for which, were the defendant not licensed or registered or authorized by a consent, permit, certificate or otherwise, he or she would be liable to a penalty, the defendant must prove that he or she is licensed or registered or authorized by a consent, permit, certificate or otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Process not objectionable on other grounds
bcl:section.bcl:text: No information, summons, conviction, order or process is deemed to charge 2 offences or to be uncertain merely because it states that the alleged offence was committed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in different modes, or
in respect of one or other of several articles, either conjunctively or disjunctively.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An objection to an information for a defect apparent on its face must be made by motion to quash the information before the defendant has pleaded, and after that only by leave of the justice before whom the trial takes place.

A justice may, on the trial of an information, amend the information or a particular furnished under section 97 (3) to make the information or particular conform to the evidence if there appears to be a variance between the evidence and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the charge in the information, or
the charge in the information

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as amended, or
as it would have been if amended in conformity with any particular furnished under section 97 (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may, at any stage of the trial, amend the information as may be necessary if it appears

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the information

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: fails to state or states defectively anything that is required to constitute the offence,
does not negative an exception that should be negatived, or
is in any way defective in substance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and the matters to be alleged in the proposed amendment are disclosed by the evidence taken on the trial, or
that the information is in any way defective in form.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A variation between the information and the evidence taken on the trial is not material with respect to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time when the offence is alleged to have been committed, if it is proved that the information was laid within the prescribed period of limitation, or
the place where the subject matter of the proceedings is alleged to have arisen, if it is proved that it arose in the territorial jurisdiction of the justice who holds the trial.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The justice must, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made, consider

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the evidence taken on the trial, if any,
the circumstances of the case,
whether the defendant has been misled or prejudiced in his or her defence by a variance, error or omission mentioned in subsection (2) or (3), and
whether, having regard to the merits of the case, the proposed amendment can be made without injustice being done.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the opinion of the justice, the defendant has been misled or prejudiced in his or her defence by an error or omission in the information, the justice may adjourn the trial, and may make an order for the payment of costs resulting from the necessity of amendment as the justice considers desirable.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In sections 102 to 114, appeal court means the Supreme Court.
Unless otherwise provided by law,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant may appeal to the appeal court

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: from a conviction or order made against the defendant, or
against a sentence passed on the defendant,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the informant, the Attorney General or the Attorney General's agent in proceedings under this Act may appeal to the appeal court

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: from an order dismissing an information, or
against a sentence passed on a defendant, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person in respect of whom a confirming order or an order of detention is made under section 91, 92 or 93 may appeal to the appeal court from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the confirming order, or
the order of detention.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An appeal under section 102 must be heard at the sittings of the appeal court that is held nearest to the place where the conviction or order was made or sentence passed, but the appeal court may, on the application of one of the parties, appoint a place for the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appellant who proposes to appeal to the appeal court must give notice of appeal in a manner and within a period directed by the Criminal Rules of the Supreme Court of British Columbia.
The appeal court may at any time extend the time within which a notice of appeal may be given.
If an appeal to the appeal court is from a conviction imposing imprisonment without alternative punishment, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remain in custody until the appeal is heard, or
enter into a recognizance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an appeal to the appeal court is from a conviction or order adjudging that a fine or sum of money be paid and imposing a term of imprisonment in default of payment, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remain in custody until the appeal is heard,
enter into a recognizance, or
deposit with the justice the amount of the fine or the sum of money to be paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an appeal to the appeal court is from a conviction or order adjudging that a fine or sum of money be paid but not imposing a term of imprisonment in default of payment, the appellant must comply with subsection (2) (b) or (c).
A recognizance entered into under section 105

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be in Form 18,

must be entered into before a judge of the Supreme Court or a justice who has jurisdiction in the territorial division in which the conviction or order was made, in an amount the court or justice directs,
may be required to be entered into with one or more sureties, and
may, if it is not entered into by one or more sureties, be required to be accompanied by a deposit of a sum of money the court or justice directs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: It is a condition of a recognizance under section 105 that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appellant, if he or she was the defendant in the proceedings before the justice, will appear personally at the sittings of the appeal court at which the appeal is to be heard, and
the appellant will abide the judgment of the appeal court on the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal court has, with respect to a recognizance that appears to it to be insufficient, defective or invalid, the same powers that the Supreme Court has under section 116 (4).
If an appellant is in custody and a recognizance is entered into under section 105, an order for discharge in Form 22 must be issued by the person who takes the recognizance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Payment of fine is not waiver of appeal, etc.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person does not waive his or her right of appeal under section 102 merely because he or she pays the fine imposed on conviction without in any way indicating an intention to appeal or reserving the right to appeal.
A conviction, order or sentence is deemed not to have been appealed against until the contrary is shown.

If a notice of appeal is filed, the clerk of the appeal court must obtain from the court from which the appeal is brought the conviction, order or order of dismissal and all other material in the possession of that court in connection with the proceedings before the time when the appeal is to be heard, or within a further time the appeal court directs, and the material must be kept by the clerk of the court with the records of the appeal court.
An appeal must not be dismissed by the appeal court merely because a person other than the appellant failed to comply with the provisions of this Act relating to appeals.
If an appeal is taken under section 102 in respect of a conviction, acquittal, sentence or order, sections 683 to 689, except section 686 (5), of the Criminal Code apply.

If an appeal court orders a new trial, it must be held before a court other than the court that tried the defendant in the first instance, unless the appeal court directs that the new trial be held before the court that tried the defendant in the first instance.

Despite subsection (1), if an appeal is taken under section 102 and if, because of the condition of the trial record in the court appealed from or for any other reason, the appeal court, on application of the defendant, the informant, the Attorney General or the Attorney General's agent, is of the opinion that the interests of justice would be better served by hearing and determining the appeal by holding a new trial, the appeal court may order that the appeal be heard by way of a new trial and sections 8, 56 to 65, 74 to 79 and 97 to 100 apply except to the extent that they may be inconsistent with sections 102 to 114.

The appeal court may, for hearing and determining an appeal under subsection (3), permit the evidence of any witness taken before the justice to be read if that evidence has been authenticated in accordance with section 540 of the Criminal Code, and if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appellant and respondent consent,
the appeal court is satisfied that the attendance of the witness cannot reasonably be obtained, or
because of the formal nature of the evidence or otherwise, the court is satisfied that the opposite party will not be prejudiced.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any evidence read under the authority of subsection (4) has the same effect as if the witness had given the evidence before the appeal court.

If an appeal is taken under subsection (3) against sentence, the appeal court must, unless the sentence is one set by law, consider the fitness of the sentence appealed against, and may, on evidence, if any, it thinks fit to require or receive, by order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dismiss the appeal, or
vary the sentence within the limits prescribed by law for the offence of which the defendant was convicted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making an order under subsection (6) (b), the appeal court may take into account any time spent in custody by the defendant as a result of the offence.
Under subsection (3), if an appeal is based on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an objection to an information or any process, judgment must not be given in favour of the appellant for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an alleged defect in the information or process in substance or in form, or
any variance between the information or process and the evidence adduced at the trial

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless it is shown that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the objection was made at the trial, and
an adjournment of the trial was refused, even though the variance referred to in subparagraph (ii) had deceived or misled the appellant, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a defect in a conviction or order, judgment must not be given in favour of the appellant, but the court must make an order curing the defect.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The appeal court may adjourn the hearing of the appeal, as necessary.
The appeal court may, on proof that notice of an appeal has been given and that the appeal has not been proceeded with or has been abandoned, order that the appeal be dismissed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an appeal is heard and determined, or is abandoned or is dismissed for want of prosecution, the appeal court may make any order with respect to costs that it considers just and reasonable.
Section 79 (3) applies to an order under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 82 applies to an appeal to an appeal court or by way of stated case.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement of conviction or order by appeal court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A conviction or order made by the appeal court may be enforced

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the same manner as if it had been made by a justice, or
by process of the appeal court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an appeal taken against a conviction or order adjudging payment of a sum of money is dismissed, the justice who made the conviction or order, or a justice for the same territorial division, may issue a warrant of committal as if no appeal had been taken.

If a conviction or order made by an appeal court is to be enforced by a justice, the clerk of the appeal court must send to the justice the conviction or order and all writings relating to it, except the notice of intention to appeal and any recognizance.
A party to proceedings to which this Act applies or the Attorney General may appeal against a conviction, order, determination or other proceeding of a justice on the ground that it is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: erroneous in point of law, or
in excess of jurisdiction

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: by applying to the justice to state a case setting out the facts as found by the justice and the grounds on which the proceedings are questioned.
An application to state a case must be made, and the case must be stated within the period and in the manner directed by the Supreme Court Civil Rules, if any.
If, for the purposes of subsection (2), there are no Supreme Court Civil Rules that apply,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: must be in writing and be directed to the justice, and
must be served on the justice by leaving with the justice a copy of it within 30 clear days after the time when the adjudication that is questioned was made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the case must be stated and signed by the justice

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within one month after the application was made, and
after the recognizance referred to in section 116 has been entered into,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appellant must, within 15 clear days after receiving the stated case,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if he or she is the informant, or the Attorney General or their respective counsel or agent, cause a copy of the stated case to be served on the defendant, or other persons the Supreme Court directs, and transmit the stated case to the Supreme Court, and

if he or she is the defendant, or other person appealing, cause a copy of the stated case to be filed in the office of the Registrar of the Supreme Court, and the registrar must at once send a copy to the Attorney General, or as the Attorney General direct, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appellant must, if he or she is the informant, or the Attorney General or their respective counsel or agent, file in the office of the Registrar of the Supreme Court proof of service of the stated case not later than 7 days after the last day for service of the stated case.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Supreme Court may, on application by the appellant, extend the times referred to in the Supreme Court Civil Rules for the application to state a case or for the stating of the case, or the times referred to in subsection (3) (b) or (c), but an extension must not be granted for more than 30 days.

The appellant must, at the time the appellant makes the application and before a case is stated, enter into a recognizance, in Form 18, before the justice or a justice who has the same jurisdiction, with or without sureties and in an amount that the justice considers proper, on the condition that the appellant prosecute the appeal without delay and submit to the judgment of the Supreme Court.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the application is made by the Attorney General or by counsel acting on behalf of the Attorney General.

If an appellant is in custody, the justice must order that he or she be released, if the appellant's recognizance contains a further condition that the appellant will appear before that justice or another justice within 10 days after the judgment of the Supreme Court has been given, to abide the judgment, unless the judgment from which the appeal is taken is reversed.

If the recognizance appears to the Supreme Court to be insufficient, defective or invalid, the Supreme Court may permit the substitution of a new and sufficient recognizance to be entered into before it, and the substituted recognizance is, for all purposes, as effectual as if it had been entered into at the time the appellant made the application and before the case was stated.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure when justice dies, quits office or is unable to act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, pending an application for a stated case, the justice dies, quits office or is unable to act, the appellant may, on giving notice to the respondent, apply to the Supreme Court to state a case, and if a case is then stated, it must be dealt with as if it had been stated by the justice.
The appellant must, before a case is stated by the Supreme Court under this section, enter into a recognizance under section 116.

If a justice to whom an application to state a case is made considers that the application is frivolous, the justice may refuse to state a case, and must, at the request of the appellant, issue to the appellant a certificate of the refusal.
The justice must not refuse to state a case if the application is made by or at the direction of the Attorney General or counsel acting on behalf of the Attorney General.

If the justice refuses to state a case, the appellant may apply to the Supreme Court, on an affidavit setting out the facts, for an order directing the justice and the respondent to show cause why a case should not be stated.

If an application is made under subsection (1), the Supreme Court may make the order or dismiss the application, with or without payment of costs by the appellant or the justice, as it considers appropriate in the circumstances.
If an order is made under this section, the justice must, on being served with a copy of it and on the appellant entering into a recognizance under section 116 (1), state a case accordingly.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A writ of certiorari or other writ is not required to remove a conviction, order or other determination in relation to which a case is stated for the purpose of obtaining the judgment, determination or opinion of the Supreme Court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a case is stated under this Act, the Supreme Court must hear and determine the grounds of appeal, and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: affirm, reverse or modify the conviction, order or determination,
send the case back to the justice for amendment and deliver judgment after it has been amended, or
remit the matter to the justice with the opinion of the Supreme Court,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and may make

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other order in relation to the matter that it considers proper, and
any order with respect to costs that it considers proper and that could be made by a justice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in section 119 (2), an order for the payment of costs must not be made against the justice who states a case.

If the Supreme Court has rendered its decision on a stated case, the justice in relation to whose adjudication the case has been stated or a justice exercising the same jurisdiction has the same authority to enforce a conviction, order or determination that has been affirmed, amended or made by the Supreme Court as the justice would have had if a case had not been stated.
An order of the Supreme Court may be enforced by its own process.

A person for whom a case is stated in respect of an adjudication of a justice from which the person is entitled to an appeal under section 102 must be taken to have abandoned all his or her rights of appeal under that section.
If it is provided by law that no appeal lies from a conviction or order, no appeal by way of a stated case lies from that conviction or order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal to Court of Appeal on question of law

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal to the Court of Appeal may, with leave of a justice of that court, be taken on any ground that involves a question of law alone against a decision of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a court in respect of an appeal under section 102, or
the Supreme Court in respect of a stated case under section 121.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 673 to 689 of the Criminal Code apply, with the necessary changes and so far as applicable, to an appeal under this section, and the Court of Appeal may grant a new trial.
Despite subsection (2), the Court of Appeal may make any order with respect to costs that it considers proper in relation to an appeal under this section.
The decision of the Court of Appeal may be enforced in the same manner as if it had been made by the justice before whom the proceedings were originally heard and determined.
The Rules of Court made by the Court of Appeal under section 482 of the Criminal Code apply, with the necessary changes and so far as applicable, to an appeal to the Court of Appeal under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A conviction or order must not be removed by certiorari if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appeal was taken, whether or not the appeal has been carried to a conclusion, or
the defendant appeared and pleaded and the merits were tried, and an appeal might have been taken but the defendant did not appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A conviction, order or warrant for enforcing a conviction or order must not, on being removed by certiorari, be held to be invalid for an irregularity, informality or insufficiency in it if the court before which the question is raised, on perusal of the evidence, is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an offence of the nature described in the conviction, order or warrant was committed,
there was jurisdiction to make the conviction or order or to issue the warrant, and
the punishment imposed, if any, was not in excess of the punishment that might lawfully have been imposed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court referred to in subsection (1) has the same powers to deal with the proceedings in the manner that it considers proper that are conferred on a court to which an appeal might have been taken.

If, in proceedings to which section 126 applies, the court is satisfied that a person was properly convicted of an offence but the punishment that was imposed is greater than the punishment that might have lawfully been imposed, the court must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct the sentence,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the punishment is a fine, by imposing a fine that does not exceed the maximum fine that might lawfully have been imposed,

if the punishment is imprisonment, and the person has not served a term of imprisonment under the sentence that is equal to or greater than the term of imprisonment that might lawfully have been imposed, by imposing a term of imprisonment that does not exceed the maximum term of imprisonment that might lawfully have been imposed, or
if the punishment is a fine and imprisonment, by imposing a punishment in accordance with subparagraph (i) or (ii), as the case requires, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remit the matter to the justice and direct the justice to impose a punishment that is not greater than the punishment that may be lawfully imposed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an adjudication is varied under section 126, or under subsection (1) of this section, the conviction and warrant of committal, if any, must be amended to conform with the adjudication as varied.
Any statement that appears in a conviction and is sufficient for the conviction is sufficient for the information, summons, order or warrant in which it appears in the proceedings.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Without limiting sections 126 and 127, those sections are deemed to apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the statement of the adjudication, or of any other matter or thing, is in the past tense instead of in the present tense,
the punishment imposed is less than the punishment that might by law have been imposed for the offence that appears by the evidence to have been committed, or

there has been an omission to negative circumstances, the existence of which would make the act complained of lawful, whether those circumstances are stated by way of exception or otherwise in the provision under which the offence is charged, or are stated in another provision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warrant of committal not void for defect in form
bcl:section.bcl:text: A warrant of committal must not, on certiorari or habeas corpus, be held to be void merely because of a defect in it if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is alleged in the warrant that the defendant was convicted, and
there is a valid conviction to sustain the warrant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No action against official when conviction, order or proceeding quashed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an application is made to quash a conviction, order or other proceeding made or held by a justice on the ground that the justice exceeded his or her jurisdiction, the court to which the application is made may, in quashing the conviction, order or other proceeding, order that civil proceedings must not be taken against the justice or against any officer who acted under the conviction, order or other proceeding, or under any warrant issued to enforce it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The forms set out in the Schedule or forms of similar effect, varied to suit the case, are deemed to be good, valid and sufficient in the circumstances for which they are provided.
No justice is required to attach or affix a seal to any writing or process that the justice is authorized to issue and in respect of which a form is set out in the Schedule.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Attorney General, make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Attorney General, make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining an expression used in section 10.1 that is not otherwise defined in this Act;
prescribing the form and content of the violation tickets issued under section 14;
prescribing a form for the purpose of section 15.4 (1);

prescribing instructions that must be printed beside or on the reverse side of the violation ticket that is given or mailed to or served on the person who is alleged to have contravened the enactment;

only for the purposes of an agreement between the Province and Canada under the Contraventions Act (Canada), exercising the authority under paragraphs (a.1), (a.2), (a.3) and (g) in both the English and French languages;

respecting the electronic issuance, reception, creation, completion, signing, identification, transmission, storage or reproduction, or conversion from either paper or electronic format to the other format, of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a violation ticket other than an eTicket, or
a certificate of service of a violation ticket other than an eCertificate of service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the issuance, reception, creation, completion, identification, transmission, storage or reproduction of an eTicket or an eCertificate of service;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: issue a violation ticket under section 14 (1) (a) or under either section 14 (1) (a) or (b),
issue an appearance notice under section 39 (1),
issue both a violation ticket and an appearance notice, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (4), prescribing, for the purposes of sections 14 and 16 (1), fines for a contravention of an enactment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if paid on or before the 30th day, and
if paid after the 30th day

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from the date of service under section 14 (5) or mailing under section 14 (6) of a violation ticket;

[Not enacted.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For greater certainty, if one fine is prescribed under subsection (2) (d), the fine is both

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fine that applies if paid on or before the 30th day from the date of service under section 14 (5) or mailing under section 14 (6) of a violation ticket, and
the fine that applies if paid after the 30th day from the date of service under section 14 (5) or mailing under section 14 (6) of a violation ticket.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2005-1-7.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: If, in any proceeding, matter or thing to which this Act applies, express provision has not been made in this Act or only partial provision has been made, the provisions of the Criminal Code relating to offences punishable on summary conviction apply, with the necessary changes and so far as applicable, as if its provisions were enacted in and formed part of this Act.
